BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the wind slabs that are forming in all aspects represent the main danger.
Without question, it is inadvisable to engage in winter sport activities.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the extensive wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase. Numerous natural avalanches are to be expected, even very large ones. Single winter sport participants can release avalanches very easily.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In the course of the day the wind slabs will increase in size substantially. Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow are bonding poorly with the old snowpack in all aspects.
Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area wind and new snow. As a consequence of new snow and wind, further wind slabs will form. The wind slabs will form in all aspects.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above the tree line. As a consequence of the strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form. These avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on wind-loaded slopes. The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases. In particular above the tree line these avalanche prone locations are more widespread.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area over a wide area 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. 10 to 20 cm of snow will fall on Saturday above approximately 1000 m. The wind will be moderate to strong in some localities. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The fresh wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack in all aspects and above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The wind will be strong over a wide area. New snow and wind slabs require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs that are forming in all aspects represent the main danger.
Backcountry touring calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects. Numerous avalanches are possible, even very large ones in isolated cases. The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In the course of the day the wind slabs will increase in size. The new snow and wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack.
Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area wind and new snow. As a consequence of new snow and wind, wind slabs will form. The wind slabs will form in all aspects.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Above approximately 1200 m snow will fall until the early morning. Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. From early morning the wind will be moderate to strong.
Since Sunday avalanche prone wind slabs formed in particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as at intermediate and high altitudes. These can be released by a single winter sport participant.
The fresh snow of yesterday as well as the deep wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence above approximately 2200 m.
Medium-sized and, in many cases, large dry avalanches are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 50 cm of snow has fallen since Sunday. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes. Backcountry touring calls for careful route selection.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Over a wide area 40 to 60 cm of snow will fall on Saturday above approximately 1600 m. During the course of the night as a consequence of the snowfall there will be a gradual increase in the avalanche danger. At high altitude and in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. The fresh wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The weather conditions during the course of the night will give rise to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area. The new snow is bonding poorly with the old snowpack in many places in particular on steep shady slopes. Over a wide area new snow is lying on soft layers. As a consequence of a sometimes strong wind, easily released wind slabs will form. In particular at low altitude a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area 5 to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Sunday above approximately 1500 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Above approximately 1200 m snow fell yesterday. The sometimes moderate wind will transport the new snow significantly. In the course of the day sometimes large wind slabs will form.
The fresh snow of yesterday as well as the wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant,. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.
Medium-sized and large dry avalanches are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 15 to 25 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since the early morning above approximately 1500 m. The new snow can be released naturally in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution. The sometimes strong wind will transport the new snow.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Down to low altitudes snow has fallen. The somewhat older wind slabs are covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise. In particular in the northwest and at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions the avalanche prone locations are more widespread.
Since Saturday The northwesterly wind will transport the new snow significantly. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses. The soft wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant on north, east and south facing slopes above approximately 2000 m. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack here. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible.
In areas close to the tree line a precarious avalanche situation will be encountered in some regions. Meticulous route selection is appropriate.

On very steep slopes medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible as a consequence of new snow and wind.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
40 to 60 cm of snow, but less in some localities, has fallen since Wednesday above approximately 2000 m.
The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack. On wind-loaded slopes small and medium-sized avalanches were released. On very steep slopes several medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches occurred naturally.
The old snowpack is hard. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. Below approximately 1800 m thus far only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Sunday: In particular in the regions of the north exposed to the foehn wind moderate northwesterly wind. The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs of yesterday represent the main danger. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
Medium-sized dry avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of the snowfall.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 15 to 25 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell yesterday above approximately 1600 m. In isolated cases new snow is lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack. In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Over a wide area 40 to 80 cm of snow will fall on Saturday above approximately 1600 m. During the course of the night as a consequence of the snowfall there will be a gradual increase in the avalanche danger. At high altitude and in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. The fresh wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The weather conditions during the course of the night will give rise to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area. The new snow is bonding poorly with the old snowpack in many places in particular on steep shady slopes. Over a wide area new snow is lying on soft layers. As a consequence of a sometimes strong wind, easily released wind slabs will form. In particular at low altitude a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area 5 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Sunday above approximately 1500 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Above approximately 900 m snow will fall over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The large quantity of fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on very steep shady slopes. Single skiers can release avalanches easily, including large ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: At elevated altitudes a considerable avalanche danger will prevail. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs that are forming in all aspects represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects. Numerous avalanches are possible, even very large ones in isolated cases. The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In the course of the day the wind slabs will increase in size. The new snow and wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack.
Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area wind and new snow. As a consequence of new snow and wind, wind slabs will form. The wind slabs will form in all aspects.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Above approximately 900 m snow will fall over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be quite well bonded. The large quantity of fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs are bonding quite well with the old snowpack. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on very steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The sometimes strong wind will transport the new snow.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Down to low altitudes snow fell on Friday.
In some localities mostly small wind slabs formed. They are barely recognisable. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust in all aspects.

The wind slabs can be released in isolated cases at their margins. Especially transitions into gullies and bowls places that are protected from the wind, in particular on very steep slopes.
There is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
15 to 25 cm of snow has fallen since Wednesday above approximately 2000 m. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Especially on steep sunny slopes only a little snow is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous and its surface has a crust that is strong in many cases. This applies below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Sunday: Northerly wind. The avalanche danger will increase but remain within the current danger level.

BulletinMeasurements.highlights: Above approximately 900 m snow will fall over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming above all adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep, little used north, northeast and northwest facing slopes above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be favourable at intermediate and high altitudes. In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as at high altitude mostly small wind slabs will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Slight increase in avalanche danger in the course of the day. Fresh wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strengthening wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form in the afternoon above the tree line. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.

In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. In isolated cases the gliding avalanches are quite large. This applies in the regions with a lot of snow. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 30 cm of snow will fall. Afternoon: The wind will be moderate in some regions. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at elevated altitudes. They can in some cases be released easily.

The new snow will be deposited on surface hoar in some places in areas close to the tree line. The new snow of the last few days is lying on a crust in all aspects below approximately 2600 m. The old snowpack will be stable over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind. Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Sunday above approximately 1000 m. The fresh wind slabs can be released easily.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above the tree line. As a consequence of the strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form. These avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on wind-loaded slopes. The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases. In particular above the tree line these avalanche prone locations are more widespread.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area over a wide area 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. 10 to 20 cm of snow will fall on Saturday above approximately 1300 m. The wind will be moderate to strong in some localities. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The fresh wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack in all aspects and above the tree line. At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The wind will be strong over a wide area. New snow and wind slabs require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Down to 1000 m snow has fallen over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area some new snow to above approximately 1000 m. Small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized dry avalanches are possible as a consequence of the snowfall.
In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow has fallen since yesterday. Over a wide area thus far only a little snow is lying.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust. These avalanche prone locations are covered with new snow and are difficult to recognise. Backcountry touring calls for caution and restraint.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in all aspects above approximately 1800 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of new snow and wind the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent in the evening. In the evening potentially danger level 1 (low) will be reached above approximately 1800 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Light snowfall above approximately 1800 m: This situation will give rise in the evening to favourable bonding of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow will be deposited on a quite favourable old snowpack in all aspects.
The avalanche danger will increase a little during the day. Fresh wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strengthening wind, mostly small wind slabs will form in the afternoon above the tree line. These can be released in isolated cases. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 10 to 30 cm of snow will fall above approximately 1000 m. Evening and first half of night: The wind will be moderate in some regions. The new snow and wind slabs will be deposited on a crust in particular on sunny slopes at high altitude.
